I recall this pull request, see CALCITE-2609 and CALCITE-563

The PR looks good to me modulo `RuntimeException` use for error signaling and error messages.
Certain messages start with lowercase, and it probably makes sense to elaborate messages so they help user to understand and resolve the issue.

CalciteResources would enable use of translated messages.

I don't think it blocks the PR, however I think proper exception messages are more important than, for instance, commit messages
I've pushed patches afer review.
What is the JIRA for this PR?
This is not a good idea. A lot of rules transform RelNodes into equivalent ones with different field names. It's foolish to try to fight this.
Can you please create a JIRA case for this? We'll discuss there.

Do you intend to commit this, or was this just a test of CI?

If you want to commit, add the spaces in the middle of the folder names. Trailing spaces is just too perverse. And add comments to travis.yml, that the spaces are deliberate. With these changes, +1.

If you don't intend to commit, close the PR.

Commits squashed into a single one

I wonder what is the use of the rule though.

Is it to ease the translation of SQL to the storage systems that don't support IS_DISTINCT?
If that is the case, IS_TRUE/IS_NOT_TRUE is likely unsupported there either.

> I wonder what is the use of the rule though.
> 
> Is it to ease the translation of SQL to the storage systems that don't support IS_DISTINCT?
> If that is the case, IS_TRUE/IS_NOT_TRUE is likely unsupported there either.

I think this rewrite is in there because "is distinct" could be translated to more generic constructs.

It seems to me that this conversion is invoked 2 ways:
* a rewrite is done during `SqlToRel` phase
* and there is FilterRemoveIsNotDistinctFromRule - which I guess is there because not everyone uses `sql2rel` and for those cases this transformation was not accessible - (similarily to like IN/OR translation - the file history goes back to "reformat eigenbase" - so I can't check the original issue to somewhat validate my assumptions)

Note: as long as the cast to a non-nullable type is going away I think the original issue is addressed; the original issue arises from the fact that RexToLix translator expects to be able to get an "executable" tree; however in case one of the arguments is a literal null, the translation is not possible - althoght its impossible to reach the branch which is problematic.

Can anyone help to review my code ?

Is it possible to separate this PR into 2 ? 
1. Geode transformation of disjunctions back into `IN`: 
```sql
 foo = 1 or foo = 2 or foo = 3
-- equivalent to (but much faster in geode) 
foo in SET(1, 2, 3)
```
([IN SET](http://geode.apache.org/docs/guide/17/developing/query_select/the_where_clause.html#the_where_clause__section_AC12146509F141378E493078540950C7) in something specific to geode)
2. Support for temporal types and searches (DATE, TIME, TIMESTAMP etc.)

Please note that this will implementation will have to be changed once `IN` will become a flat RexCall.
Read [discussion](https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/e2c55425383fed7d7a76d452af8ecda61a74b787bdef38657ea41fe4@%3Cdev.calcite.apache.org%3E).
Closing this PR and splitting it into two as suggested by Andrei

@kk19ag Please see my comments in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2625 and revise the PR.

Update on this issue: I'm recently investigating why the tests hang. The cause is that a test case [`StreamTest#testStreamToRelationJoin` ](https://github.com/apache/calcite/blob/ee5b2f75032aa166e4923a9c90f302811cf23bab/core/src/test/java/org/apache/calcite/test/StreamTest.java#L271) causes a sequence of rule matches repeatedly triggering forever. This is the only errored test case.

I'm debugging the rule match process and haven't yet found the reason. Among the rules applied for this test case, only [`PruneEmptyRules#Union`](https://github.com/apache/calcite/blob/3fa29455664bec0056c436491b369e0cd72242ea/core/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/rel/rules/PruneEmptyRules.java#L75) uses `unordered` and is possibly affected by this change. But I don't think it's the problem of this specific rule. Some other unintended interactions among other rules cause this problem. I'll keep this issue updated once I found the reason.

@laurentgo , I also noticed that you defined PI as a dynamic function when you did CALCITE-1557. Any idea why you did that? It seems wrong.

> @laurentgo , I also noticed that you defined PI as a dynamic function when you did CALCITE-1557. Any idea why you did that? It seems wrong.

Yes, it's wrong. I think I was confused between dynamic and niladic, but I'm not even sure PI should be niladic, and people should probably use `PI()` instead of `PI`

> Addressed comments. Can you advise on where existing tests for this rule are? I can expand.
